H0.text: A galvanic cell is the electrochemical system in which connecting a magnesium rod to an underground steel pipeline protects the pipeline from corrosion, with the magnesium rod acting as the anode because magnesium (e° = −2.37 V) is more readily oxidized than iron (e° = −0.45 V).

H1.text: Anode cell is the electrochemical cell in which the magnesium rod, being more easily oxidized (e° = −2.37 V) than iron (e° = −0.45 V), acts as the anode when connected to an underground steel pipeline to protect the pipeline from corrosion.

H2.text: Stimulation cell is the electrochemical cell in which a magnesium rod, which has a more easily oxidized potential (e° = –2.37 V) than iron (e° = –0.45 V), acts as the anode to protect an underground steel pipeline from corrosion.

H3.text: Voltaic cell is a type of electrochemical cell in which a magnesium rod acts as the anode when it is connected to an underground steel pipeline to protect the pipeline from corrosion, because magnesium (e° = −2.37 V) is more easily oxidized than iron (e° = −0.45 V).

A4.text: Magnesium has the most negative electropotential of the three (see galvanic series) and is more suitable for areas where the electrolyte (soil or water) resistivity is higher.

A5.text: reduction of water or solvated protons may evolve hydrogen atoms on the cathode surface, for instance leading to hydrogen embrittlement or to disbonding of the coating.

A6.text: In order for galvanic cathodic protection to work, the anode must possess a lower (that is, more negative) electrode potential than that of the cathode (the target structure to be protected).

A7.text: Galvanic anodes are selected because they have a more 'active' voltage than the metal of the target structure (typically steel).
